docs.text: Hello World! ¶ The index.md in the /docs folder is the homepage you see here. The folders in /docs appear as the main sections on the navigation bar. The notes appear as pages within these sections. For example, [[Note 1]] in Topic 1
docs.title: Home

docs.text: The index.md in the /docs folder is the homepage you see here. The folders in /docs appear as the main sections on the navigation bar. The notes appear as pages within these sections. For example, [[Note 1]] in Topic 1
docs.title: Hello World!

docs.text: LaTeX Math Support ¶ LaTeX math is supported using MathJax. Inline math looks like \(f(x) = x^2\) . The input for this is $f(x) = x^2$ . Use $...$ . For a block of math, use $$...$$ on separate lines $$ F(x) = \int^a_b \frac{1}{2}x^4 $$ gives \[ F(x) = \int^a_b \frac{1}{2}x^4 \]
docs.title: LaTeX Math Support

docs.text: LaTeX math is supported using MathJax. Inline math looks like \(f(x) = x^2\) . The input for this is $f(x) = x^2$ . Use $...$ . For a block of math, use $$...$$ on separate lines $$ F(x) = \int^a_b \frac{1}{2}x^4 $$ gives \[ F(x) = \int^a_b \frac{1}{2}x^4 \]
docs.title: LaTeX Math Support

docs.text: Mermaid diagrams ¶ Here's the example from MkDocs Material documentation : graph LR A[Start] --> B{Error?}; B -->|Yes| C[Hmm...]; C --> D[Debug]; D --> B; B ---->|No| E[Yay!];
docs.title: Mermaid diagrams

docs.text: Text Formatting ¶ You can have lists like this first second third Or checklist lists to Get things done Also, get highlights and strikethroughs as above (similar to Obsidian). More formatting options for your webpage here . (but not compatible with Obsidian)
docs.title: Text Formatting

docs.text: You can have lists like this first second third Or checklist lists to Get things done Also, get highlights and strikethroughs as above (similar to Obsidian). More formatting options for your webpage here . (but not compatible with Obsidian)
docs.title: Text Formatting

docs.text: Note 1 ¶ Example: link to Mermaid Diagrams under Features bubble_sort.py def bubble_sort ( items ): for i in range ( len ( items )): for j in range ( len ( items ) - 1 - i ): if items [ j ] > items [ j + 1 ]: items [ j ], items [ j + 1 ] = items [ j + 1 ], items [ j ] Also, check this out: The range () function is used to generate a sequence of numbers. Cool: C C++ #include <stdio.h> int main ( void ) { printf ( "Hello world! \n " ); return 0 ; } #include <iostream> int main ( void ) { std :: cout << "Hello world!" << std :: endl ; return 0 ; } Data tales: ¶ Method Description GET :material-check: Fetch resource PUT :material-check-all: Update resource DELETE :material-close: Delete resource Formating: ¶ Text can be deleted and replacement text added . This can also be combined into one a single operation. Highlighting is also possible and comments can be added inline . Formatting can also be applied to blocks by putting the opening and closing tags on separate lines and adding new lines between the tags and the content. Images ¶ Task Lists ¶ Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit Vestibulum convallis sit amet nisi a tincidunt In hac habitasse platea dictumst In scelerisque nibh non dolor mollis congue sed et metus Praesent sed risus massa Aenean pretium efficitur erat, donec pharetra, ligula non scelerisque
docs.title: Note 1

docs.text: Example: link to Mermaid Diagrams under Features bubble_sort.py def bubble_sort ( items ): for i in range ( len ( items )): for j in range ( len ( items ) - 1 - i ): if items [ j ] > items [ j + 1 ]: items [ j ], items [ j + 1 ] = items [ j + 1 ], items [ j ] Also, check this out: The range () function is used to generate a sequence of numbers. Cool: C C++ #include <stdio.h> int main ( void ) { printf ( "Hello world! \n " ); return 0 ; } #include <iostream> int main ( void ) { std :: cout << "Hello world!" << std :: endl ; return 0 ; }
docs.title: Note 1
